We identified four distinct cardiolipin species associated with LysoPA in biosynthesis: CL(16:1(9Z)/18:1(11Z)/20:0/20:4(5Z,8Z,11Z,14Z)), CL(a-13:0/i-22:0/i-24:0/i-20:0), CL(i-12:0/i-14:0/i-13:0/i-19:0), and CL(14:1(11Z)/16:1(9Z)/18:1(11Z)/18:1(11Z)). Furthermore, we found that LysoPA is also involved in de novo <process>triacylglycerol biosynthesis</process> through its interaction with specific triacylglycerol species, including TG(a-25:0/i-19:0/a-13:0).

Conclusion:
Our study provides novel insights into the role of LysoPA in cardiolipin and <process>triacylglycerol biosynthesis</process>. These findings highlight the importance of LysoPA in maintaining cellular lipid <process>homeostasis</process> and may have implications for understanding <process>lipid metabolism</process> disorders and potential therapeutic targets for related diseases. Title: Glycerol 3-Phosphate Involvement in Cardiolipin and <process>Phospholipid Biosynthesis</process>: A Comprehensive Analysis of Diverse CL Structures

Abstract:
Glycerol 3-phosphate (G3P) is a crucial molecule involved in various cellular processes, including <process>lipid metabolism</process> and energy production. In this study, we focus on the role of G3P in cardiolipin (CL) and <process>phospholipid biosynthesis</process>. Cardiolipin is an <role>essential</role> phospholipid found primarily in the <disposition>inner mitochondrial membrane</disposition>, playing a vital role in maintaining mitochondrial function and integrity. We have identified several G3P-dependent pathways for CL biosynthesis, including CL(i-13:0/i-12:0/i-12:0/i-12:0), CL(14:1(9Z)/18:3(9Z,12Z,15Z)/20:4(8Z,11Z,14Z,17Z)/22:1(13Z)), CL(14:0/14:1(11Z)/15:0/27:1(11Z)), CL(18:1(9Z)/16:0/17:0cycw7/17:0cycw7), and CL(i-12:0/a-17:0/i-21:0/i-13:0). Additionally, we have investigated the role of G3P in <process>phospholipid biosynthesis</process>, particularly CL(14:1(9Z)/18:1(9Z)/18:2(9Z,12Z)/20:4(5Z,8Z,11Z,14Z)). Our findings highlight the diverse roles of G3P in CL and <process>phospholipid biosynthesis</process>, providing insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying these processes and their potential implications for mitochondrial function and overall cellular health.
